Understate: The claim "Our high school graduation rate is the highest on record" may be understating the actual graduation rate based on the expert's statement that "as many as a quarter of our students aren’t even finishing high school."
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as the expert mentions that tracking high school graduation rates has proven to be a tough stat to track and that there have been flaws in the national data.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that a high graduation rate is indicative of success in education, but the expert mentions that over the next 10 years, nearly half of all new jobs will require education beyond high school.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert's statement about the need for education beyond high school suggests that there may be alternative explanations for the increase in high school graduation rates, such as more students pursuing college degrees.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact mentioned by the expert that up to 25 percent of Americans drop out of high school.
Exaggerate: The claim may be exaggerating the achievements of the administration by stating that the high school graduation rate is the highest on record without sufficient evidence or support.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times because of the difficulties in accurately tracking high school graduation rates and the flaws in the national data.
